questions.text: A 28-year-old man has lenticonus and end stage renal disease now. His maternal uncle also died of the same illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alport’s syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Presentation of male patient with lenticonus and end stage renal disease with a family history of renal disease is highly suggestive of Alport syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD): it is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys. It is an adult-onset condition, and lenticonus (cone-shaped deformity of the lens) is not a typical feature of ADPKD.

 

Option B: Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD): it is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects the kidneys and liver. It often presents in childhood, and patients may develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) at a young age. Lenticonus is not a characteristic feature of ARPKD.

 

Option C: Oxalosis is a condition where excessive oxalate accumulates in various organs, including the kidneys. It can lead to renal failure, but lenticonus is not a typical manifestation of oxalosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Alport Syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities. It results from mutations affecting type IV collagen, essential for normal function in the kidneys, inner ear, and eyes.

 

Genes Involved:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 922)

choices.text: Her C3 levels will be low
No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

questions.text: A 7 yrs old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

 

Option C:

 

In minimal change disease (MCD), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, renal biopsies do not show IgG deposits or C3 deposition. MCD is characterized by the effacement of podocyte foot processes and is often responsive to corticosteroids.

 

The clinical symptoms and the findings in the stem of the question (child with generalized swelling because of reduced serum protein secondary to massive proteinuria with urinary lipid casts) are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. The commonest cause in a child of nephrotic syndrome is lipoid nephrosis or minimal change disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IgA nephropathy is a common cause of glomerulonephritis that often presents with hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection, making it less likely in this case without a history of hematuria.

 

Option B: Low C3 levels are typically associated with complement-mediated conditions such as post-infectious glomerulonephritis or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typically seen in minimal change disease.

 

Option D: Alport syndrome is characterized by hematuria, progressive renal failure, and hearing loss, and is caused by genetic mutations affecting type IV collagen; it is not the most likely diagnosis given the absence of hematuria and the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a child presenting with nephrotic syndrome and no hematuria, evidenced by proteinuria and lipiduria, is minimal change disease. This condition does not show IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy, and electron microscopy would reveal effacement of the podocyte foot processes.

 

(Ref: Robbin’s 10th/ 914)

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnosis for a condition having mutation in COL4A5 chain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alport’s syndrome

Option A:

Alport's syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the basement membrane of the kidney, ear, and eye. Mutations in genes like COL4A5 can lead to Alport's syndrome.

Explanation:

Option B: Goodpasture's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the lungs and kidneys. It is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen.

Option C: Thin Membrane Disease: It affects collagen alpha chain type 4

Option D: Nodular glomerulosclerosis is a histological pattern seen in diabetic nephropathy, where there is nodular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. It is not associated with mutations in COL4A5.

Educational objective:

Mutations in genes like COL4A5 can lead to Alport's syndrome.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 922)

questions.text: The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid resistance nephrotic syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NPHS 2

Option B:

NPHS2 mutations are commonly associated with autosomal recessive steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Podocin is a protein that plays a crucial role in the structure and function of the glomerular filtration barrier.

Explanation:

Option A: ACE is not typically associated with idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome.

Option C: HOX11 (also known as TLX1) is associated with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL), not nephrotic syndrome.

Option D: PAX genes are involved in various developmental processes and are not specifically associated with nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid resistance nephrotic syndrome is NPHS2.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 915)

questions.text: A person with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following would be the most likely histological finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

 

Option A:

 

Reflux nephropathy is characterized by chronic inflammation and scarring due to vesicoureteral reflux. Nephrotic range proteinuria suggests glomerular involvement, and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Direct quote…‘FSGS occurs as a component of the adaptive response to loss of renal tissue in advanced stage of other renal disorders such as reflux nephropathy, hypertensive nephropathy and  unilateral renal agenesis.’

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Membranous glomerulopathy is characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, often forming immune complexes.

 

Option B: Nodular glomerulosclerosis is not a common feature of reflux nephropathy. It is seen with diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option D: Proliferative glomerulonephritis with crescents is more associated with nephritic range proteinuria rather than nephrotic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reflux nephropathy and nephrotic range proteinuria are commonly seen in Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

 

(Ref Robbins 10th/ 915)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with worsening renal function and proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows nodular glomerulosclerosis with eosinophilic deposits in the mesangium and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence staining reveals granular deposits of IgG and C3. The Kimmelstiel Wilson lesions are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic nephropathy

Option A:

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis, are a pathognomonic finding in diabetic nephropathy. These lesions consist of nodular deposits of mesangial matrix within the glomerulus. The KW lesions are associated with progressive renal damage in the context of diabetes.

Explanation:

Option B: Analgesic nephropathy refers to kidney damage caused by the long-term use of certain analgesic medications, particularly those containing phenacetin. It is characterized by chronic interstitial nephritis, papillary necrosis, and renal papillary atrophy.

Option C: RPGN is a term used to describe a clinical syndrome characterized by a rapid decline in renal function. Various forms of glomerulonephritis, including anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease and immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, can present as RPGN.

Option D: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis that occurs following certain streptococcal infections, particularly streptococcal pharyngitis. It is characterized by diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis with prominent inflammatory changes.

Educational objective:

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis, are a pathognomonic finding in diabetic nephropathy.

 

(Ref: Robbin 10th/ 923)

choices.text: Decrease in plasma protein concentration
Increase in plasma protein concentration
Reduced plasma osmotic pressure
Sodium and water retention

questions.text: The cause of edema in nephritic syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium and water retention

Option D:

Sodium and water retention: This is the correct answer. In nephritic syndrome, the primary mechanism for edema is the retention of sodium and water due to reduced glomerular filtration rate and altered renal perfusion, which can be a direct consequence of glomerular inflammation.

Sodium and water retention (option d) the primary cause of edema formation in nephritic syndrome but the loss of plasma proteins may also contribute to the same.

Explanation:

Option A: Decrease in plasma protein concentration While a decrease in plasma proteins can contribute to edema through reduced colloid osmotic pressure, it is more characteristic of nephrotic rather than nephritic syndrome.

Option B: Increase in plasma protein concentration: This option is incorrect, as nephritic syndrome does not typically involve an increase in plasma protein concentration.

Option C: Reduced plasma osmotic pressure: This could theoretically contribute to edema; however, in the context of nephritic syndrome, it is not the primary cause.

Educational Objective:

In nephritic syndrome, edema is primarily caused by sodium and water retention due to the body's response to kidney inflammation and injury is essential for guiding appropriate treatment strategies.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 906)

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia with renal failure
All of the above

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and decreased urine output. Physical examination reveals pallor and petechiae. In hemolytic uremic syndrome there is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

Option D:

Explanation:

Option A: Thrombocytopenia with renal failure: Thrombocytopenia is a hallmark feature of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), resulting from the formation of microthrombi in small blood vessels. Renal failure is a common complication due to the microvascular thrombosis affecting the kidneys.

Option B: Normal coagulative profile: In HUS, the coagulative profile is normal.

Option C: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia: MAHA is a characteristic feature of HUS. It results from the fragmentation of red blood cells as they traverse through damaged small blood vessels, leading to schistocytes or fragmented red blood cells.

Educational objective:

The classic triad of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS),  includes thrombocytopenia with renal failure due to microthrombi, a normal coagulative profile distinguishing it from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and micro-angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) characterized by hemolysis of red blood cells due to vascular injury.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 938)

questions.text: Tram track appearance on histopathology of kidney is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

 

Option B:

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis involves both mesangial and subendothelial immune complex deposits. It typically presents with a lobular appearance on histopathology and a “tram track appearance”.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the presence of subepithelial immune complex deposits, leading to a characteristic spike and dome appearance on histopathology.

 

Option C: IgA nephropathy is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium of the glomeruli. It usually does not present with tram track appearance.

 

Option D: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is associated with the formation of crescents in Bowman's space due to severe inflammation and glomerular injury. It does not typically present with tram track appearance.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 917)

questions.text: IgA depositions in mesangial cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Berger disease

Option B:

Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): This is the correct answer. It is defined by the deposition of IgA immune complexes within the mesangium of the glomeruli, seen as mesangial proliferation and IgA deposits on immunofluorescence.

  • IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger disease, is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangial area of the glomerulus.

Explanation:

Option A: Goodpasture’s Syndrome: Characterized by anti-GBM antibodies leading to linear immunofluorescence. Goodpasture's does not feature IgA deposition but instead has antibodies against the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.

Option C: Crescentic Glomerulonephritis: This refers to a severe form of glomerulonephritis marked by crescent formation. While it can be due to IgA nephropathy, it can also arise from other causes and does not specifically imply IgA deposition.

Option D: Alport Syndrome: A hereditary disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, leading to glomerular basement membrane abnormalities. It does not involve IgA deposits.

Educational Objective:

The presence of mesangial IgA immune complexes is pathognomonic for Berger's disease, also known as IgA nephropathy. In contrast, Goodpasture’s syndrome involves anti-GBM antibodies, crescentic glomerulonephritis may or may not involve IgA depending on the underlying cause, and Alport syndrome is a genetic condition with a distinct pathophysiology not involving IgA.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 920)

choices.text: Elevated blood urea and creatinine
Increased ASO titre

questions.text: The following is not a feature of acute post streptococcal glomerulonephritis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal C3

Option A:

Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation. Typically it is associated with decreased levels of serum complement, including C3. Therefore, having a normal C3 level would be unusual in the context of APSGN.

Explanation:

Option B: Hypertension is a common feature of acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The mechanism involves increased fluid retention.

Option C: APSGN can lead to a rise in blood urea and creatinine levels due to impaired renal function caused by glomerular inflammation.

Option D: Streptococcal infections, particularly group A streptococcus, can lead to the production of anti-streptolysin O (ASO) antibodies. Elevated ASO titres are a characteristic feature of streptococcal infections and are often used to support the diagnosis of recent streptococcal infections.

Educational objective: 

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is associated with decreased levels of serum complement, including C3.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 906)

choices.text: Crescents in most of the glomeruli
Loss of foot processes of epithelial cells
Subendothelial electron dense deposits
The thickening of glomerular capillary wall

questions.text: Histological hallmark of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crescents in most of glomeruli

Option A:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by the presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Crescents result from the accumulation of proliferating parietal epithelial cells, macrophages, and fibrin within Bowman's space.

Explanation:

Option B: Loss of foot processes can lead to proteinuria  and is a histological finding of minimal change disease and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis rather than RPGN.

Option C: Subendothelial electron dense deposits are associated with conditions like MPGN 

Option D: Thickening of the glomerular capillary wall is a characteristic finding in conditions like diabetic nephropathy and membranous nephropathy. It is not a specific feature of RPGN.

Educational objective:

Histological hallmark of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is crescents in most of the glomeruli.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 909)
